c74object.name: randdist
c74object.description: Generate random numbers with a variety of distributions

objarg.name: distribution
objarg.description: The distribution that is accessed when randdist is instantiated.

objarg.name: parameter list
objarg.description: The parameter list for a given distribution. See below for details on parameters.

method.name: bang
method.description: Generate a random number, based on the distribution defined. Default is uniform.

method.name: distlist
method.description: This message tells randdist to output a list of numbers instead of a single float. The elements in the list represent separate queries of a type of randomness. This can be useful for outputting a topology of values based on a specific distribution.

method.name: float
method.description: Scalar for the random numbers generated when randdist receives a bang.

method.name: int
method.description: An int has the same effect as the [distlist] message.

method.name: list
method.description: The size of this list is dependent on which distribution is set up for the object. For example, a gaussian distribution would require a list of one element, and that element would pertain to the 'sigma' parameter. See the various distributions listed in this reference for full details.

method.name: loadbang
method.description: If this message is issued after randdist is instantiated, the object will store the current seed status for the next time that the patch is loaded. This can be useful in generated predictable behavior and shapes.

method.name: nonparametric
method.description:
The non-parameteric message allows the user to draw/edit their own distribution. For each list element that is input, thre is an index and a weight. The index is a chosen value, and the weight is how frequently that value is chosen. A value of 1. equates to that index being chosen most of the time. A value of zero will not allow the index to appear in the output. If there are more than one non-zero values in the list, the probability is shared between them.
Example: the list [0. 0. 1. 0. 0.1] will output a zero (2) most of the time, and every once in a while will output a 4.

method.name: tellmeeverything
method.description: Output all information about the object's state to the Max window.

method.name: version
method.description: Print version information to the Max window.

method.name: gaussian
method.description: The normal distribution. A common probability-based distribution. Read more here.

method.name: gaussian_tail
method.description: The normal distribution with a decay-tail property. Read more here and here.

method.name: bivariate_gaussian
method.description: Returns a pair of random deviates from within the boundaries of sigma x and y, respectively. rho is a correlation measure between the two for what is returned, and should lie between 1 and -1. Read more here.

method.name: exponential
method.description: Describes the time between events in a Poisson point process. Read more here.

method.name: erlang
method.description: A two-parameter probability distribution. The first is a positive integer, and the second a positive real number.

method.name: laplace
method.description: The "double exponential distribution". This distribution is basically a mirror of two exponential distibutions. The width is representative of the spread in the exponential function(s) that is drawn from when numbers are generated.

method.name: exppow
method.description: This function returns a random variate from the exponential power distribution with scale parameter and exponent. The scale is the height of the maximum returned value, and the exponent is how tightly fitted the sigmoid is as it hovers around zero.

method.name: cauchy
method.description: The distribution of the ratio of independent normally distributed random variables. Read more here.

method.name: rayleigh
method.description: A continuous probability distribution for positive-valued random variables, named after Lord Rayleigh. Sigma is equivalent to a scale parameter. Read more here.

method.name: rayleigh_tail
method.description: Similar to the rayleigh distribution, but with a lower limit of 'a'.

method.name: landau
method.description: A probability distribution with a "fat tail" along the x axis. Mean/variance are undefined. Read more here.

method.name: levy
method.description: A probability distribution for a non-negative variable. Read more here.

method.name: levy_skew
method.description: The levy distribution with skew applied. Skew (skewness) must be a float between -1. and 1.

method.name: gamma
method.description: The alpha parameter shapes the function drawn from and beta functions as a rate parameter. Read more here.

method.name: uniform
method.description: Equally probability distribution. 'a' and 'b' represent the locations on the x axis in which the number will be generated. Read more here.

method.name: lognormal
method.description: A continuous probability distribution of a random variable whose logarithm is normally distributed. Read more here.

method.name: chisq
method.description: The chi-squared distribution is the distribution of a sum of the squares of k independent standard normal variables. Read more here.

method.name: f
method.description: The f-distribution is a continuous probability distribution that arises frequently as the null distribution of a test statistic, most notably in the analysis of variance. Read more here.

method.name: t
method.description: The t-distribution is any member of a family of continuous probability distributions that arises when estimating the mean of a normally distributed population in situations where the sample size is small and population standard deviation is unknown. Read more here.

method.name: beta
method.description: A family of continuous probability distributions defined on the interval [0, 1] parametrized by two positive shape parameters, denoted by Î± and Î², that appear as exponents of the random variable and control the shape of the distribution. Read more here.

method.name: logistic
method.description: A continuous probability distribution in which its cumulative distribution function is the logistic function. This distribution has heavier tails compared to normal distribution. Read more here.

method.name: pareto
method.description: A power law probability distribution that is used in description of many types of observable phenomena. Read more here.

method.name: weibull
method.description: A continuous probability distribution that was originally applied to describe particle size. Read more here.

method.name: gumbel1
method.description: A distribution mainly used in the analysis of extreme values and event-history modeling. Read more here.

method.name: gumbel2
method.description: Similar to the weibull distribution. Read more here.

method.name: dirichlet
method.description: A multivariate generalization of the beta distribution. The list here designates the number of dimensions of K. Read more here.

method.name: poisson
method.description: A discrete probability distribution that expresses the probability of a number of events within a fixed interval of time/space (IF these events occur with a known constant rate and independently of the time since the last event). Read more here.

method.name: bernoulli
method.description: A probability distribution of any single experiment that asks a yesâno question; the question results in a boolean-valued outcome, a single bit of information whose value is true with probability p and false outcome with probability q in the equation [q = 1 - p]. Read more here.

method.name: binomial
method.description: The binomial distribution is frequently used to model the number of successes in a sample of size n drawn with replacement from a population of size N. Read more here.

method.name: multinomial

arg.name: k floats (returns a list of k elements)

method.description: A generalization of the binomial distribution, which is based on 'n'. K specifies the number of categories. Read more here.

method.name: negative_binomial
method.description: A discrete probability distribution of the number of successes in a sequence of independent and identically distributed Bernoulli trials before a specified (non-random) number of failures (denoted r) occurs. Read more here.

method.name: pascal
method.description: A special case of the negative binomial distribution. Read more here.

method.name: geometric
method.description: The geometric distribution gives the probability that the first occurrence of success requires k independent trials, each with success probability p.

method.name: hypergeometric
method.description: A discrete probability distribution that describes the probability of k successes in N draws from a finite population (of size n) that contains exactly k objects with that feature, wherein each draw is either a success or a failure. Read more here. n1 is the number of elements of "type 1" and n2 elements of "type 2". This setup yields the probability of obtaining k elements of "type 1" in t samples from the population without replacement. See the reference function for more information.

method.name: multivariate_hypergeometric
method.description: Refer to the probability mass function for more information on the functionality of this distribution. Read more here.

method.name: logarithmic
method.description: A discrete probability distribution derived from the Maclaurin series expansion. Read more here.

entry.name: Inlet 1 [anything]
entry.description: Send a message to the randdist object.

entry.name: Outlet 1 [list or float]
entry.description: Generated numbers as either a single float or list of floats.
